TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {5817=Two Color Disruptive: 1935 � Introduced in 1935, the two color disruptive pattern consisted of dark grey and dark brown (Dunkelgrau RAL 7021 & Dunkelbraun RAL 7017) applied in a two-thirds/one-third pattern}
textBeforeTable: Ambush Camouflage (Hinterhalt-Tarnung): August 1944 � In order to achieve a more standardized pattern, camouflage paint began to be applied at the factory.  �Ambush Camouflage�, consisted of a base of dark yellow (Dunkelgelb) with olive-green and red-brown (Olivgr�n & Rotbraun) patches. On top of this pattern were added small contrasting dots of all three paints. Late War Years Pz VI B in three color disruptive camouflage Replica StuG III in three color disruptive camouflage
textAfterTable: Restored Hetzer in Ambush Camo (Virginia Museum of Military Vehicles) Restored Hetzer in Ambush Camo (Virginia Museum of Military Vehicles) September 1944 - Tanks were left in the red primer (Oxidrot RAL 3009) with no base coat and only limited camouflage of olive-green and/or red-brown (Olivgr�n & Rotbraun) applied at the factory. By the end of October 1944, this was expanded to include dark yellow, olive green and red brown (Dunkelgelb, Olivgr�n and Rotbraun) applied in limited amounts over the red primer.
